Well, I actually want to move ahead to another topic.
We have a lot on our plate today.
I went to Skid Row.
I mean this was a piece that I did with one of our producers, Corey Turner.

And we did a two-part piece or series on Skid Row in Los Angeles, and it was shortly after a woman who had dementia was dumped just wearing her hospital gown downtown in, you know, a very rough, dangerous area.
We'll explain.
We're talking to you because you are 40 years old.
Correct.
True.

And now Los Angeles prosecutors have filed criminal charges against Kaiser Permanente who they alleged did the dumping, and I believe Kaiser, you know, has said, you know, we apologize if - and we're looking into it.

It's really amazing to me how much I learned about how different municipalities, like the smaller cities around Los Angeles will just use L.A.'s downtown Skid Row as a place to dump prisoners - they drop them off with a paper bag full of, you know, their soap and a couple of dollars they've earned.
and what responsibility, I guess, do larger structures like the hospital system, like Kaiser or other police departments have to really not view urban areas as a dumping ground?
I guess, Callie, I'll start with you.
Well, they have the ultimate responsibility, which is, you know, to - there is a service of caring for people.
Hospitals particularly.
I mean there are oaths there that people take, there's responsibility, there's rules, there's laws.
So this shouldn't be happening on any level and certainly on a human level.
But the fact that it's going on is, I guess, can't be that shocking.

And this is - I'm looking at the fact that when we decided in this country - and I say we because there were lots of policymakers involved in this - that we were not going to fund services to mental health services in the way that we should.
Lots of those folks ended on the street.
So in effect they were dumped as well.
Maybe they didn't come from the doors of a hospital, sometimes they did.
But there they were.
And so we're dumping not just in the Skid Rows of L.A.
but we're dumping in communities across this country.
And by the way, it's not just urban communities.
This is happening in small rural communities as well.
So we got a problem about dealing with the, quote-unquote, unwashed and unwanted.
And I think it comes home to haunt us.
And I hope that this is an example that would wake up folks and - because it could by your relatives.
You know, Bob, at this point in time there are certain areas that are considered okay to dump people and certain areas that are not.
Does this mean that we're going to have to have a larger discussion about the not-in-my-backyard syndrome?
Because if you dispersed all the people on Skid Row they would have to go somewhere, often back to cities and towns that dumped them there.
You know, I remember back in the mid-90s, when Giuliani came in and I left New York around '95 or so.
Then I came back in '98.
And when I came back, you know, Giuliani been in power for about five years by that point.
I was wondering where have all the homeless people gone.
Well, then I took a trip to Seattle and I think they all ended up there.
Because you move people around - if you enforce laws that or, like, make it real difficult for people, they're just going to, like you said, they're going to move someplace else.
They're not going to just disappear all of a sudden, not become homeless.
There are many, many issues that needs to be address with this, whether it mental health, whether it's AIDS, whether it's poverty just in general that have to be addressed with this.
So yeah, the discussion needs to be wider than just, well, we're dumping people here in Los Angeles, because that's not really going to solve the problem by itself.
Michael, you're executive director of the New York Civil Rights Coalition.
To what degree are issues like homelessness and mental health and all that, do these fall under civil rights concerns?
Well, they fall under human rights concerns, because a civil rights society just doesn't maltreat its citizens.
It doesn't maltreat.
It doesn't disrespect.
It doesn't punish.
It doesn't abandon.
It doesn't desert.
It does not dump its elderly, its sick, its poor onto Skid Row.
Not a civilized society.
Skid Row is the blight and the shame of a quite prosperous nation, probably the most prosperous nation in the world.

And that patient suffering from dementia or all kinds of diseases - of all the diseases, dementia - that they could be dumped, abandoned, consigned to Skid Row is to me paramount to administering a death penalty.
If true, there is criminal and civil liability.
But as senior citizens might say, those responsible for such types of depraved indifference to life should not just be put in jail, they should be put underneath the jail.
But society has got to do something about poverty.
It has to do something about homelessness other than sweep the homeless away, other than put the homeless out of the public spaces and public places.
And we've got to do something about homeless.
As Bob said, we've got to do something about mental health issues.
We have to do something about health issues and health maintenance and insurance.
And we've got to get - we've got to build affordable housing.
And for those people who can't live on their own, there have to be group homes and group housing so that they will have social services.
But we've got - we have to stop declaring a war on the poor and renew our war on poverty.
